Award.AwardTitle: Translating extracellular ligand perception into a cytosolic Ca2+ signal: characterizing the role plant elicitor peptides and their receptor play in innate immune responses
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on a signal transduction system involved in plant cell immune signaling; an overall aim is to identify molecular mechanisms that allow perception of pathogenic microbes by plant cell membrane receptor proteins and translation of this perception to defense responses. An essential step in the signaling cascade is a cytosolic Ca2+ elevation that evokes downstream defense programs. Studies will focus on a family of Plant Elicitor Peptides (Peps) and their cell membrane receptor (PEPR1). A model of how Pep binding to the PEPR1 receptor leads to cytosolic Ca2+ elevation will be tested by the investigators. Preliminary studies undertaken by the investigators indicate that the PEPR1 receptor has guanylyl cyclase activity. The project will investigate whether cyclic guanylyl monophosphate (cGMP), a signaling molecule in cells, is generated in plant cells by the receptor in response to pathogen cues causing Pep peptide generation, and if the cGMP production elevates cytosolic Ca2+ due to the opening of a cyclic nucleotide gated ion channel in the cell membrane. These early steps in the immune signaling cascade will be linked to downstream defense responses such as the generation of antimicrobial molecules that limit growth of a virulent pathogen (Pseudomonas syringae) and hypersensitive response/programmed cell death response to an avirulent pathogen (P. syringae avrRpt2).

The Principal Investigator of the project has a history of recruiting high school students to work with graduate students in the laboratory, as well as accessing minority undergraduate programs and involving these students in research. This outreach and training will continue during the proposed project. The Principal Investigator has an ongoing interaction with a biology teacher at a local high school and will work with this teacher to recruit high school students to participate, along with undergraduate students, in the research activity of the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cells are the basic structural and functional unit of life in all organisms. They pattern their function to respond to numerous external conditions. They must thusly translate extracellular cues into the activation of intracellular signaling cascades that allow for cells to modify their function, responding to and adapting to external conditions. Everything from the beginning (e.g. sperm perceiving signals directing them towards eggs) to the end (immune cell perception of pathogen invasion and reprogramming to engulf and destroy invader as well as themselves) of life involves cellular systems that perceive signals. Further, cell must translate signal perception to specific adaptive cell-level responses that aid in maintaining fitness and survival of the whole organism. As primarily sessile organisms, most plants have an extra challenge; they cannot run, they cannot hide, their cells must adapt for the whole organism to survive! Cells, across all kingdoms of life, use common ‘tool kits’ to facilitate signal perception and translation of these signals to reprogram cell function in the face of external stresses to an organism as well as orchestrate cell responses to organismal development cues (for example, a response to a hormone) to coordinate organism function.

 

This project focuses on characterizing how plants use proteins and small secondary messenger molecules in signaling cascades to translate signal perception to altered cell function. Since plants do not have mobile sentry cells akin to the white blood cells of a mammalian immune system, each plant cell is capable of evoking an immune response to perception of a pathogenic microbe invading the plant interior. Specific steps in the plant immune cascade and genetic components of the plant immune system were identified. Fundamental knowledge was generated that informs our understanding of how plants can better respond to pathogenic microbes. This research revealed new information about how cells can activate an immune response to alert neighboring cells within a plant to better defend against pathogens and avoid spread of an infection. Studies generated an increased understanding of the molecular mechanisms that allow a receptor protein localized at the cell outer membrane to activate downstream signaling to pattern the plant cell immune response. The roles specific messenger molecules (such as cyclic nucleotides, calcium ions, calcium binding proteins, and reactive oxygen molecules such as hydrogen peroxide) play in the signaling cascade were characterized.

 

The work undertaken as part of this project also revealed new ways in which plant cells can activate responses to plant hormones and signaling peptides. In each bud or growing tip of a leaf, stem or root, plants have a region of meristematic, or stem cells that can be directed to either produce differentiated daughter cells (to form new shoots, leaves, or roots) or maintained as undifferentiated, pluripotent stem cells. The cues received from surrounding cells provide the information necessary to pattern the fate of the stem cells; the specific cues are a family of small peptides that act as signals in the organism developmental process. These peptides are recognized by a cell membrane surface receptor protein that activates a signaling cascade determining stem cell fate. The project generated new information about this stem cell signaling cascade in plants.

 

In a fashion similar to animals, plants have steroid hormones (called brassinosteroid or BR) that are similar to testosterone. The plant hormone BR also is a growth-promoting hormone; cells increase in size and undergo global changes in gene expression upon hormone perception. In this regard, knowledge about BR signaling could have import to crop productivity in terms of increased growth and other developmental changes. The project identified new signaling cascades activated by plant cell perception of the BR hormone.

 

Studies also addressed how plants sort out these signaling cascades, increasing understanding of how cells shuttle the downstream steps (involving similar proteins and molecules) into different outcomes, depending on which signal is perceived.

 

Numerous refereed journal articles, invited presentations at international conferences, and reports at science society meetings were generated to report these findings. The project included some broader impacts that assisted in training a new generation of scientifically literate members of the work force. High school students and undergraduate college students did independent study projects mentored by graduate students and post-doctoral research fellows. Many of these young scientists levered this training to continue developing careers in the plant biology and molecular genetics research disciplines. Programs were also developed to link the research to public understanding of science. For example, numerous seminars to the general public were delivered by the Principal Investigator of the project. The PI developed workshop for current high school teachers to provide training and resources so that they can develop labs in their high school classes to have students evaluate if the foods they commonly eat contain material from genetically modified plants.
